titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Hound & Horn Records
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 03:05

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Hound & Horn records contain correspondence, drafts of writings, financial records, and ephemera relating to the literary quarterly. The records feature original letters from well-known Modernist era authors during the tenure of the journal from the late 1920s through mid 1930s, including Bryher, Jean Cocteau, E. E. Cummings, René Daumal, T. S. Eliot, Ernest Hemingway, François Mauriac, Marianne Moore, Ezra Pound, Stephen Spender, Gertrude Stein, Robert Penn Warren, William Carlos Williams, and Louis Zukosfky, among others. There are also letters from publishers and editors, copies of outgoing letters, third-party letters, financial and legal records, and scattered drafts. There are drafts, some corrected, of work by Cummings, Daumal, Bernard Faÿ, Varian Fry, James Hanley, Pound, Spender, and Williams. The Pound files contain corrected typescript drafts for Cantos XXVIII, XXIX, XXX.

langmaterial.language: Chiefly in English; some materials in French.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Hound & Horn Records is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Hound & Horn Records. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Preliminary processing was done on the Hound & Horn records at an unknown date. During reprocessing of the collection in 2011, financial and legal correspondence and a few drafts were integrated into the arrangement of correspondence in Series I. Other materials were consolidated in Series II.

bioghist.head: Hound & Horn
bioghist.p: The Hound & Horn was a literary quarterly founded by Harvard students Lincoln Kirstein and Varian Fry in 1927. Modeled on T. S. Eliot's The Criterion , it was intended to focus on student life at Harvard and work submitted by its students and alumni. The publication later broadened in scope to include modern writers. The title of the magazine was taken from Ezra Pound's poem "The White Stag": "Tis the white stag, Fame, we're a hunting, bid the world's hounds come to horn." R. P. Blackmur served as the magazine's first managing editor from 1928 to 1930, when the magazine moved its headquarters to New York. Hound & Horn ceased publication in 1934.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Hound & Horn records contain correspondence, drafts of manuscripts, financial records, and ephemera relating to the literary quarterly. The records feature original letters from well-known Modernist era authors during the tenure of the journal from the late 1920s through mid 1930s, including Bryher, Jean Cocteau, E. E. Cummings, René Daumal, T. S. Eliot, Ernest Hemingway, François Mauriac, Marianne Moore, Ezra Pound, Stephen Spender, Gertrude Stein, Robert Penn Warren, William Carlos Williams, and Louis Zukofsky, among others. There are also letters from publishers and editors, copies of outgoing letters, third-party letters, financial and legal records, and scattered drafts. There are drafts, some corrected, for work by Cummings, Daumal, Bernard Fay, Varian Fry, James Hanley, Pound, Spender, and Williams. The Pound files, for example, contain corrected typescript drafts for Cantos XXVIII, XXIX, XXX.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Correspondence, 1925-1940. II. Other Materials, 1927-1934.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by name or subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I, Correspondence, contains original letters from well-known Modernist era authors during the tenure of the journal from the late 1920s through mid 1930s, including Bryher, Jean Cocteau, E. E. Cummings, René Daumal, T. S. Eliot, Ernest Hemingway, Francois Mauriac, Marianne Moore, Ezra Pound, Stephen Spender, Gertrude Stein, Robert Penn Warren, William Carlos Williams, and Louis Zukofsky, among others. In addition to the incoming letters of authors, there are letters from publishers and editors, copies of outgoing letters in selected files, third-party letters, financial and legal records, and scattered drafts.
Manuscript drafts are documented in folder notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes draft of short story "The Cornerstone"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains draft of "Sur le bon usage litteraire de la jeunesse"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains draft of "Mr. Fry's Song of Spring"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes drafts of "The Last Voyage" and "Stoker Haslett"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes drafts of "Criterionism" and "Cantos XXVIII, XXIX, XXX"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes drafts of "The Burning Cactus" and "The Strange Death"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains draft of "Reception to the Ambassador"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Other Materials, consists of finanical records, such as checks, ledgers, and tax statements, and printed ephemera.
